abstract: Study in journal Current Biology suggests children on autism spectrum fail to adjust their breath intake as quickly as neurotypical children when they are exposed to pleasant or unpleasant smells; results could lead to way to diagnose autism in younger children.
lead_paragraph: In a small study, researchers determined that autistic children did not make the same responses to pleasant and unpleasant odors as their typically developing peers.

headline.main: Reaction to Smells May Help Diagnose Autism, Study Suggests
headline.print_headline: Child Health: Reaction to Smells May Help Diagnose Autism

snippet: In a small study, researchers determined that autistic children did not make the same responses to pleasant and unpleasant odors as their typically developing peers.
